+Miss Phoenix Yeah I consider Obama's presidency a success based on getting 
at least some healthcare reform finally passed.

Now to give you an idea of how crazy the right-wing is here since ACA 
passed there have been over 50 bills introduced in Congress that are 
attempts to overturn ACA and well as two cases presented before the Supreme 
Court to overturn at least parts of ACA.

+MrPoster42 Well, at least Obamacare seems like the president is aware of 
the issue and is trying to do something about it. That's a step in the 
right direction. It just sucks people continue to suffer whilst waiting for 
those short, slow steps to be taken.

+Miss Phoenix I put that in to make it clear I'm not trying to just cry 
about my personal health.  It is what it is and for most people it's not 
hard to find someone whose circumstance makes you seem like a spoiled child 
for complaining at all.

That said it is frustrating to have to have to work so hard for almost all 
of it to go to health costs.  Then when I look around at others who are not 
just frustrated but left without proper care entirely while we live in the 
wealthiest country in the history of the world it's just infuriating to 
hear people argue against universal healthcare.

I would like to call them cruel but in reality it is most likely just 
ignorance.  For people that have naturally good health it's not really 
shocking for them to not understand just how debilitating it is to deal 
with chronic health issues.  For instance if my health had given out prior 
to me getting my business built to the level that it can "self-run" to a 
certain degree I would lose my business since I couldn't keep up the work 
schedule.  Then everything would domino down to me being impoverished.

At least with the ACA (ie Obamacare) there is a chance for insurance 
without a full-time job but to cover a chronically ill person it still is 
going to be too much money for what you can earn on a limited income due to 
health.

Anyway obviously this is a rather large issue for me but and it's baffling 
that people can see our military budget and then still say we can't afford 
universal healthcare even though under universal healthcare the cost per 
person would drop dramatically thus being better for everyone.  It's just 
insane.

+MrPoster42 Well, I feel pretty bad for you (not in a condescending way or 
anything) but on the other hand like you said, you do still make a living 
without too much issues because of your income, and it is a lot better than 
dying due to lack of clean water for example.

+Miss Phoenix<n my country (Norway) and many others in Europe the 
healthcare is free, so why do American citizens with their countries wealth 
have to suffer?>

The Cold War instilled a huge anti-communist ideology within many.  The 
right-wing in our country pretty much analogize anything being government 
run as anti-American and a step towards being communist and inherently 
evil. 

There is also a huge propaganda machine that has many Americans convinced 
that government run healthcare comes with "death panels" (ie letting people 
just die because they cost too much) or insane waiting lists where people 
die before they can get their procedures.

In America politicians don't ever talk about facts.  It's all just buzz 
words, shouting matches, and lies.

I have huge medical expenses and am fortunate to be in upper-middle class 
financially just so it doesn't bankrupt me.  I have CVID (almost no natural 
immune system) and my treatments are about $7k a month.  Fortunately my 
yearly deductible is only $1k but that still means I pay out of pocket that 
$1k as a New Year's present every year.  Of course beyond that I pay $70 
per visit for the specialists I have to see and that is sometimes as much 
as 4-5 times per month.  Then all the prescriptions cost me about another 
$400 a month.  Add in that my mother has the same disorder so then double 
all that.  So we live together and run our family business just to make 
ends meet.

So I make good money but am still broke all the time just from medical 
expenses.  All because I was born with some wrong letters on my DNA.  But I 
can either be pissed that I wasn't born in Norway where all that would be 
free or be glad I wasn't born in rural Africa where I would have died in 
infancy.  Still it is sad that a country with our wealth completely 
neglects education and healthcare for it's people.  It's why we have gone 
from the greatest country on the planet to a country that other 
industrialized nations just shake their heads at and wonder what the hell 
we are thinking.

+MrPoster42 I feel bad for Americans for those reasons. So much poverty and 
shit, but the government spends all of its money on military (has highest 
spending in the world, with expenditures equal to that of the next 29 
countries combined!) The health care system is so broken there. My friend 
living in Ohio had to pay $200 for a 5 minute ambulance ride, and then 
nearly $2000 for a doctor to give him a blood test, some drug to combat a 
chemical that he had too much of in his body, and then send him home. He 
now can't afford to have any medical help with his massive amounts of neck 
and back pain. In my country (Norway) and many others in Europe the 
healthcare is free, so why do American citizens with their countries wealth 
have to suffer? Why with so much money and manpower, is there still 
break-ins, murders, car thefts and rapes every few minutes? It's horrible :(

+Hoganply<Ironically a good example of many Americans' genuinely tight 
grasp of self-depricative humour>

Far too many of my fellow Americans still cling to this false notion that 
we are the bastion of freedom in an otherwise tyrannical world.  To talk 
about America as not being the greatest country in the world is considered 
anti-America instead of just being acknowledged as reality.  We have the 
most wealth but we insist on spending it on guns, big guns, and bigger guns 
while neglecting healthcare, education, properly trained police, proper 
treatment for addicts and the mentally disabled, or reforming a justice 
system that is failing at every level.

We are among the top in the world in categories like gun deaths, 
incarceration rate, & obesity.

When you live in a country where people actually believe that the answer to 
reducing gun violence is more guns in the hands of more people it can be a 
bit disheartening to say the least.

There was a time when America was the best country in the world but that

who they considered to be the greatest threat to world piece had America as

+Bento Jones This is a kind of comedy known as dead-pan comedy. The teller 
of the joke says things he clearly does not believe or plays ignorant with 
an entirely straight face. Usually, it draws from a lot of subtle cultural 
knowledge (i.e. Ben Stiller's career & sense of humor) & can be difficult 
to understand, especially for people whose first language is not the 
language of the joke & if they did not grow up in the culture of the joke 
teller.

It's understood that this is a very subtle type of comedy by the people who 
made this, so they made sure include the branding & voice-over of Penn at 
the end so that anyone who wasn't immediately in on the joke would 
hopefully understand what had actually happened.
